Raising awareness about the inherent oppression of property is a matter of tearing down the illusions that keep people docile and complicit. People are taught from birth that ownership is sacred, that private property is a right. But what they’re not taught is that property is a system of domination. It’s the root of all hierarchy—land, resources, and means of production are hoarded by a few, while the rest are forced to beg for scraps or labor for pennies. That’s not a right; that’s a crime. It’s theft dressed up in laws and borders.

The first step is to expose the lie. Talk to people on the streets, in workplaces, in schools. Share stories of how the wealthy built their empires on the backs of others, how they fence off forests and rivers, how they patent life-saving medicines and charge for breath. Show them how every "mine" and "yours" is a line drawn in blood. Use art, graffiti, music, and spoken word to make the idea visceral. Let the message be felt in the gut before it’s understood in the head.

But awareness alone isn’t enough. We need to act. And we need to act *now*. Start with the small, visible thefts—take what you need, return what you can. Take food from supermarkets and give it to the hungry. Knock over a luxury car, not because it’s fun, but because it’s a symbol of the system. Burn the signs that say "No Trespassing" and plant gardens where corporate parks stand. These are not crimes; they are acts of resistance.

Build networks. Create communes where people live without the need for property. Share tools, skills, and resources freely. Teach others that cooperation is possible when the lie of scarcity is broken. The more people live outside the system, the more it will crumble.

And when the state tries to punish us for these acts, we must be unafraid. The law is just another weapon of the powerful. But every arrest, every trial, every jail cell is a platform. Use it. Tell the world why you did it. Tell them that the real crime is the system itself.

The goal isn’t just to redistribute wealth—it’s to destroy the concept of property altogether. Until the last fence is torn down and the last lock is broken, the fight continues. And I, for one, will never stop.
